The "Economic Growth Incentive Act of 1995" includes a 5-percent decrease in individual income taxes for most taxpayers. The "Economic Growth Incentive Act of 1995" includes rate reductions for taxable years beginning after 1995, with new percentages substituted for existing ones in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Technical amendments are also made to ensure the changes are implemented. The "Economic Growth Incentive Act of 1995" includes rate reductions for taxable years beginning after December 31, 1995. Amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to adjust tax rates and headings. TITLE II--INCENTIVE FOR PURCHASE OF AMERICAN-MADE PROPERTY

SEC. 201. DEDUCTION FOR GENERAL SALES TAXES ON AMERICAN-MADE TANGIBLE PERSONAL PROPERTY. Section 164 of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to allow a deduction for state and local general sales taxes on qualified sales of American-made property. The term "qualified sale" refers to any purchase of property where the total price paid by the taxpayer exceeds $500, including taxes and shipping costs. The term "American-made property" refers to tangible personal property with over 50% of the cost attributed to value added in the United States. The amendments in this section apply to taxable years starting after the enactment of this Act. TITLE III--SURFACE TRANSPORTATION PROGRAMS

SEC. 301. Repeal of Section 1002 of the Intermodal Surface Transportation Efficiency Act of 1991.

SEC. 302. Authorization of appropriations for highway programs. Section 1003(a) of the Intermodal Surface Transportation Efficiency Act of 1991 is amended to include fiscal years 1997, 1998, and 1999 in various paragraphs. The Intermodal Surface Transportation Efficiency Act of 1991 is amended to include fiscal years 1997, 1998, and 1999 in various paragraphs by updating the years mentioned in each paragraph. SEC. 303. DONOR STATE BONUS AMOUNTS amended for fiscal years 1998 and 1999 to $514,000,000 each. SEC. 304. APPOORTIONMENT ADJUSTMENTS updated to hold harmless and adjust payments for fiscal year 1999. SEC. 305. SET-ASIDE FOR 4R PROJECTS. SEC. 305. SET-ASIDE FOR 4R PROJECTS. Amends Section 118(c)(2)(A) of title 23, United States Code, for fiscal years 1997, 1998, and 1999. SEC. 308. HIGHWAY TIMBER BRIDGE PROGRAM, SEC. 309. HIGHWAY USE TAX EVASION PROJECTS, SEC. 310. SCENIC BYWAYS PROGRAM, and SEC. 311. CONSTRUCTION OF FERRY BOATS AND FERRY TERMINAL FACILITIES are all amended by inserting fiscal years 1997, 1998, and 1999. SEC. 312 amends the Intermodal Surface Transportation Efficiency Act of 1991 by extending authorization of appropriations for highway safety. SEC. 313 removes obligation limitations for sums authorized by the Act. SEC. 314 pertains to Federal Transit Act authorizations. SEC. 314 amends the Federal Transit Act authorizations for fiscal years 1997, 1998, and 1999. SEC. 315 repeals reductions in Federal Transit Act authorizations for budget compliance. SEC. 316 amends the Motor Carrier Safety Grant Program for fiscal years 1997, 1998, and 1999. SEC. 317 extends Highway Trust Fund expenditures for 2 years. SEC. 317 extends Highway Trust Fund expenditures for 2 years. TITLE IV--RELIEF FROM CREDIT CRUNCH loosens requirements on loan loss reserves. The Congress finds that the US economy has been experiencing slow growth, facing a credit crunch, with banks adopting cautious credit policies. The Federal Reserve has tried to stimulate the economy by lowering reserve requirements, but with only moderate success. State and Federal banking agencies have also loosened loan loss reserve requirements. The Congress believes that State and Federal banking agencies should ease the credit crunch by making it easier for businesses and individuals to obtain loans and leases. They should also sensibly apply requirements on loan loss reserves to not punish responsible borrowers. TITLE V--CAP ON FEDERAL EMPLOYMENT

SEC. 501. CAP ON FEDERAL EMPLOYMENT.

(a) Employment Cap--Total number of individuals employed by Federal Government cannot exceed number on date of enactment of this Act.
(b) Rescission of Appropriations--Unobligated amounts appropriated before enactment date for unfilled positions are rescinded.

TITLE VI--REDUCTION IN FEDERAL OVERHEAD EXPENSES

SEC. 601. REDUCTION OF AMOUNTS AVAILABLE TO FEDERAL AGENCIES FOR PAYING OVERHEAD EXPENSES. The text chunk discusses the rescission and reduction of appropriations for overhead expenses of Federal agencies by 10 percent. Overhead expenses are defined as any expense incurred by a Federal agency, excluding salaries, wages, and direct spending.
